guide.title: Gentoo Linux Security Project
guide.abstract: This document describes the overall Gentoo Linux Security Project

body.p: Security is a primary focus of Gentoo Linux and ensuring the confidentiality and security of our users machines is of utmost importance to us. The Gentoo Linux Security Response team is tasked with providing timely information about security vulnerabilities in Gentoo Linux, along with patches to secure those vulnerabilities. We work directly with vendors, end users and other OSS programs to ensure all security incidents are responded to quickly and professionally.
You can find a document describing the policy the security team follows to treat the vulnerabilities found in the Gentoo distribution on the Vulnerability Treatment Policy page.

Gentoo Linux Security Announcements are notifications that we send out to the community to inform them of security vulnerabilities related to Gentoo Linux or the packages contained in our portage repository. For a full list of all recent GLSAs, please see our GLSA index page.
GLSA announcements are sent to the gentoo-announce@gentoo.org mailing-list, and as a RDF feed available at http://www.gentoo.org/rdf/en/glsa-index.rdf.

body.impo: The GPG key IDs of the security team (and of all Gentoo Linux developers) can be found on the Gentoo Linux developer list. Our GPG keys can be retrieved using the pgp.mit.edu keyserver.

body.p: Gentoo Linux takes security vulnerability reports very seriously. Please send security related reports to security@gentoo.org and file a bug on bugs.gentoo.org. The Gentoo Linux Security team will ensure all security-related bug reports are responded to in a timely fashion.

ul.li: Gentoo Hardened -- bringing advanced security to Gentoo Linux
Gentoo Server -- focusing on server-specific issues, such as security and stability

body.p:
To participate in the Gentoo Security project first join the mailing list at gentoo-security@gentoo.org and sign yourself up a bugzilla account.
You may be able to talk to one of our security developers and or users in the IRC channel #gentoo-security on irc.freenode.net for more information or just to chat about the security state of existing projects.
Candidates for the GLSA coordinator role should read the GLSA coordinator guide to see what it takes to be a GLSA coordinator.
If you don't have the ability to actively help by contributing work we will always need testers to maintain the security and stability of the overall project. All development, testing, and productive comments and feedback will be greatly appreciated.
